article.title: David_Fincher

template.arg: Fincher at the Paris premiere of ''[[The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011 film)|The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo]]'' in 2012
Film director, film producer, television director, television producer, music video director

article.paragraph: David Andrew Leo Finchercite webThe Membership: Howard Kely "Jack" FincherWolfensberger: Newsletter of the Wolfensberger Family AssociationMay 2003http://www.wolfensberger.org/pages/NL_BKUP/WFA_NL/2003May.pdfNovember 4, 2010Cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/boxingandmma/3918373/Forrest-Griffin-to-show-his-police-brutality.htmlThe Daily TelegraphLondonForrest Griffin to show his police brutalityGareth ADaviesDecember 23, 2008May 1, 2010(born August 28, 1962) is an American film director, film producer, television director, television producer, and music video director. He was nominated for theAcademy Award for Best Directorfor the romantic fantasy dramaThe Curious Case of Benjamin Button (film)The Curious Case of Benjamin Button(2008) and the dramaThe Social Network(2010). For the latter, he won theGolden Globe Award for Best Directorand theBAFTA Award for Best Direction.

He is also known for having directed the psychological thrillersSeven (1995 film)Seven(1995),Fight Club(1999), the mystery thrillersZodiac (film)Zodiac(2007) andThe Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011 film)The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo(2011) andGone Girl (film)Gone Girl(2014), as well as being instrumental in the creation of the critically acclaimed U.S. television seriesHouse of Cards (U.S. TV series)House of Cards.
article.heading: Early life
article.paragraph: Fincher was born on August 28, 1962 inDenver,Colorado, the son of Claire Mae (ne Boettcher), amental health nursefromSouth Dakotawho worked in drug addiction programs, and Howard Kelly Fincher, an author fromOklahomawho worked as a reporter and bureau chief forLife (magazine)Life.cite webhttp://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,289517,00.htmlGamy Boy''Entertainment Weekly''September 19, 1997DavidHochmanOctober 11, 2014cite webhttp://www.playboy.com/articles/playboy-interview-david-fincherPLAYBOY INTERVIEW: DAVID FINCHER''Playboy''September 16, 2014StephenRebelloOctober 14, 2014Howard died of cancer in April 2003.Cite bookSwallowJamesDark Eye: The Films of David FincherDark and Light2003Reynolds & Hearn1-903111-52-811Fincher knew from a young age he wanted to go into filmmaking. When Fincher was two years old, the family moved toSan Anselmo, California, where filmmakerGeorge Lucaswas one of his neighbors.Fincher moved toAshland, Oregonin his teens, where he graduated fromAshland High School (Oregon)Ashland High School. During high school, he directed plays and designed sets and lighting after school, and was a non-union projectionist at a second-run movie theater, production assistant at the local television news stationKOBIinMedford, Oregon, and took on other odd jobs such as fry cook, busboy, and dishwasher.cite webhttp://guru.bafta.org/david-fincher-a-life-in-picturesDavid Fincher: A Life in Pictures[[BAFTA|BAFTA Guru]]19 September 201417 August 2015Inspired byButch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid(1969), Fincher began making movies at age eight with an8mm film8mm camera.http://www.biography.com/people/david-fincher-411094#aspiring-director
article.heading: Career
Early career
article.paragraph: Fincher was employed atJohn KortyKorty Filmsas a production assistant. He moved up the ranks and became a visual-effects producerand worked on the animatedTwice Upon a Time (1983 film)Twice Upon a Time(1983). He was later hired byIndustrial Light & Magicin 1983, where he was an assistant cameraman andMatte (filmmaking)mattephotographerand worked on productions forStar Wars Episode VI: Return of the JediReturn of the Jedi(1983) andIndiana Jones and the Temple of Doom(1984).cite webhttp://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/david-fincher-awards-are-just-icing-on-the-cake-1520062.htmlDavid Fincher: "Awards are just icing on the cake"''The Independent''February 1, 2009JamesMottramOctober 11, 2014In 1984, he left ILM to direct a commercial for theAmerican Cancer Societythat shows a fetus smoking a cigarette.This quickly brought Fincher to the attention of producers in Los Angeles, and he was given the chance to direct the documentaryThe Beat of the Live Drum, featuringRick Springfield, in 1985. Though he would continue to direct spots for companies likeLevi Strauss & Co.Levi's,Converse (company)Converse,Nike, Inc.Nike,Pepsi-ColaPepsi,Revlon,Sony,Coca-Cola, andChanelFincher soon discovered music videos and went on to direct many promos. He directed the video for the 1986 release of the single "We Don't Have to Take Our Clothes Off", which was the biggest commercial success for Pop/R&B singerJermaine Stewart,http://www.biography.com/people/david-fincher-411094and extensively worked withMadonna (entertainer)Madonnadirecting several of her music videos including "Express Yourself (Madonna song)Express Yourself", "Oh Father", "Vogue (Madonna song)Vogue" and "Bad Girl (Madonna song)Bad Girl".
article.heading: Propaganda Films
article.paragraph: Set on a directing career, Fincher joined video-production companyPropaganda Filmsand started off directing music videos and commercials. Like Fincher, directors such asMichael Bay,Antoine Fuqua,Michel Gondry,Spike Jonze,Alex Proyas,Paul Rachman,Mark Romanek,Zack Snyder,Gore Verbinskiand others honed their talents at Propaganda Films before moving on to feature films.
article.heading: Favourite Films
article.paragraph: In an interview withEmpire (magazine)Empiremagazine in 2008, Fincher named the following films as his favorites:Alien (film)Alien(1979),All That Jazz (film)All That Jazz(1979),All the President's Men (film)All the President's Men(1976),American Graffiti(1973),Being There(1979),Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid(1969),Cabaret (1972 film)Cabaret(1972),Chinatown (1974 film)Chinatown(1974),Citizen Kane(1941),Days of Heaven(1978),Dr. Strangelove(1964),8(1963),The Exorcist (film)The Exorcist(1973),The Godfather Part II(1974),The Graduate(1967),Jaws (film)Jaws(1975),Lawrence of Arabia (film)Lawrence of Arabia(1962),Mad Max 2(1981),Monty Python and the Holy Grail(1975),National Lampoon's Animal House(1978),Paper Moon (film)Paper Moon(1973),Rear Window(1954),Taxi Driver(1976),The Terminator(1984),The Year of Living Dangerously (film)The Year of Living Dangerously(1982), andZelig(1983).cite webFincher, Davidhttp://www.theyshootpictures.com/fincherdavid.htmThey Shoot Pictures, Don't They?
article.heading: Feature films and television
article.paragraph: After directing several music videos, Fincher's feature debut wasAlien 3(1992). While it received anAcademy AwardOscarnomination forvisual effects, the film was not well received by critics or moviegoers. Fincher became involved with several disputes with20th Century Foxover script and budget issues. InDirector's Cut: Picturing Hollywood in the 21st Century,cite webhttp://www.amazon.com/dp/082641902XDirector's Cut: Picturing Hollywood in the 21st CenturyAmazon.comSeptember 14, 2010he blames the producers for not putting the necessary trust in him. He stated in an interview withThe Guardianin 2009: "No one hated it more than me; to this day, no one hates it more than me." After this, he retreated back into the world of commercial and music video directing, including the video for theGrammy Award-winning track "Love Is Strong" (1994) byThe Rolling Stones.

In 1995, Fincher directedSeven (1995 film)Seven. The film, based on a screenplay byAndrew Kevin Walker, told the story of two detectives (played byBrad PittandMorgan Freeman) tracking down a serial killer who bases his killings on theseven deadly sins. The film grossed more than $100 million domestically (over $300 million internationally).cite webhttp://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id''Seven''1995[[Box Office Mojo]]2010-09-14

After the success ofSeven, Fincher went on to filmThe Game (1997 film)The Game(1997). The story focused on a closed-off San Francisco businessman (played byMichael Douglas) who receives an unusual gift from his younger brother (Sean Penn), in which he becomes the main player of arole-playing gamethat takes over his life. The film had middling box-office returns despite being well received by critics.citation neededAugust 2014

Fight Club(1999) is a screen adaptation ofChuck Palahniuk's 1996Fight Club (novel)novelabout an insomniac office worker who opens up a club devoted exclusively to bare knuckle fighting for men. FeaturingEdward Norton,Helena Bonham Carter, andSevencollaborator Brad Pitt, the film was an early disappointment at the box-office and received mixed reviews.Entertainment Weekly, which had originally given the film a D-,Entertainment WeeklyReview of Fight Club (1999). October 15, 1999later ranked the DVD #1 on its list of 50 Essential DVDs.Entertainment WeeklyThe 50 Essential DVDs. January 19, 2001

In 2006, the British magazineTotal FilmvotedFight Clubnumber four in the 100 Greatest Movies of All Time, beaten only byJaws (film)Jaws,Vertigo (film)VertigoandGoodfellasat 3, 2 and 1 respectively.cite webTotal Filmhttp://www.totalfilm.com/movie_news/who_is_the_greatestWho is the greatest?Total FilmSeptember 23, 2010

In 2002, Fincher followed up with the thrillerPanic Room. The film earned over $92 million at the U.S. box office. The story follows a single mother (Jodie Foster) and her daughter (Kristen Stewart) as they hide in a safe room of their new house, away from criminals (Forest Whitaker,Dwight Yoakam, andFight ClubcollaboratorJared Leto) bent on finding a missing fortune. Fincher acknowledgedPanic Roomas a more mainstream thriller, describing the film, on the DVD's audio commentary, as "[basically] a date movie" and a "really goodB movie" about "two people trapped in a closet".

Five years afterPanic Room, Fincher returned on March 2, 2007 withZodiac (film)Zodiac, an adaptation ofRobert Graysmith's books about the hunt for theZodiac Killerthat starredJake Gyllenhaal,Mark Ruffalo,Robert Downey, Jr.,Anthony Edwards, andBrian Cox (actor)Brian Cox. The first of Fincher's films to bedigital cinematographyshot digitally, the majority of the film was recorded on aDigital cinematography camerasThompson Viper Film Stream Camera. However, high-speed film cameras were used for the Blue Rock Springs and Presidio Heights murder scenes for the slow-motion shots.Zodiac Director's Cut DVD, 2nd Disc, Visual Effects featurette.It was originally to be released in the fall of 2006 but was pushed back after Fincher refused to cut 20 minutes off the film.

Zodiacwas one of the best-reviewed films of that year, with only two other 2007 films appearing on more top-10 lists (No Country for Old Men (film)No Country for Old MenandThere Will Be Blood).Best of 2007 CriticsTop10. Criticstop10.com. Retrieved on 2014-02-01.However, the film struggled at the box office in the U.S., earning only $33 million, but did well overseas with a foreign gross of $51.7 million. Worldwide,Zodiacwas a decent success.cite webhttp://www.boxofficereport.com/ybon/2007gross.shtml2007 Box OfficeBox Office ReportJanuary 6, 2009September 23, 2010Despite an aggressive campaign by the studio, expectations surrounding Robert Downey, Jr.'s supporting performance, Fincher's direction and Vanderbilt's adapted script, the film did not earn a singleAcademy Awardnomination.Nominees. 80th Annual Academy Awards. Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. oscars.org

A story about life and death,The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (film)The Curious Case of Benjamin Buttonis an adaptation ofF. Scott Fitzgerald'sThe Curious Case of Benjamin Button (short story)short story of the same name. The film was Fincher's third with Brad Pitt. The film started shooting in November 2006 in New Orleans, before moving on to the Virgin Islands, Montreal, and L.A. BothZodiacand this film are co-productions ofParamount PicturesandWarner Bros.The budget for the film was estimated at $150 million, partly due to the CGI effects used to reverse the aging in Pitt's character. It received 13 nominations at the81st Academy Awards, including Fincher's first nomination forAcademy Award for Best DirectorBest Director. It won threeAcademy AwardsforAcademy Award for Best Art DirectionBest Art Direction,Academy Award for Best MakeupBest Makeup, andAcademy Award for Best Visual EffectsBest Visual Effects.

Fincher directed the 2010 filmThe Social Network, about the legal battles ofMark Zuckerbergand the founding ofFacebook. The film features an Oscar-winning screenplay byAaron Sorkin, adapted from the bookThe Accidental Billionaires. Featuring a young cast ensemble, the film was produced byScott Rudin,Kevin SpaceyandMichael DeLuca. Filming started in October 2009cite webhttp://www.slashfilm.com/2009/09/22/confirmed-eisenberg-timberlake-and-garfield-cast-in-david-finchers-the-social-networkConfirmed: Eisenberg, Timberlake and Garfield Cast in David Fincher's The Social Network"Slashfilm.comSeptember 22, 2009September 23, 2010and was released a year later, to critical acclaim.Trent ReznorandAtticus Rosscreated the Oscar-winning soundtrack for the film. Fincher had long been a fan of Reznor's work inNine Inch Nails, even putting a remix of "Closer (Nine Inch Nails song)Closer" in the beginning ofSevenand directing the music video for "Only (Nine Inch Nails song)Only". The film went on to win many awards, including four Golden Globes (includingGolden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture DramaBest Motion Picture Drama,Golden Globe Award for Best DirectorBest Director,Golden Globe Award for Best ScreenplayBest ScreenplayandGolden Globe Award for Best Original ScoreBest Original Score), three BAFTAs (including Best Direction), and threeAcademy AwardsforAcademy Award for Best Writing (Adapted Screenplay)Best Adapted Screenplay,Academy Award for Best Original ScoreBest Original Score, andAcademy Award for Best Film EditingBest Film Editing.cite newshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/film/2011/jan/17/golden-globes-ricky-gervais-colin-firth-social-networkGolden Globes: Colin Firth crowned while The Social Network wins lion's shareJanuary 17, 2011GuardianJanuary 20, 2011LondonXanBrooks

Fincher directed the American version ofThe Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011 film)The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, which was based on theThe Girl with the Dragon TattoobookbyStieg Larsson, with a script written bySteven Zaillian. The film was shot in Sweden, withRooney Mara(who played Erica Albright inThe Social Network) as Lisbeth Salander,Daniel Craigas Mikael Blomkvist,Robin Wright (actress)Robin Wrightas Erika Berger,Stellan Skarsgrdas Martin Vanger andChristopher Plummeras Henrik Vanger. The film was released on December 21, 2011.Dragon Tattoowriter Steve Zaillian is in the early stage of scriptingThe Girl Who Played with Fire, which Fincher has the option to direct. While he has not yet committed to the project, the Oscar-nominated filmmaker has admitted that (should he sign on) he would prefer to shoot both the second and third Millennium book adaptations back-to-back, for both practical and artistic purposes.cite webhttp://insidemovies.ew.com/2012/01/02/dragon-tattoo-sequel-girl-who-played-with-fire/'Dragon Tattoo' sequel still on track, Sony saysJanuary 3, 2012EW.comJanuary 3, 2012cite webhttp://screenrant.com/girl-played-fire-dragon-tattoo-sequel-sandy-145697/‘Girl with the Dragon Tattoo’ Sequel is Still Moving ForwardJanuary 3, 2012ScreenRant.comJanuary 3, 2012Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross composed the soundtrack for the film (their second collaboration with Fincher).cite webhttp://www.slashfilm.com/trent-reznor-scoring-david-finchers-version-the-girl-dragon-tattoo/Trent Reznor Scoring David Fincher's Version of "The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo"January 7, 2011SlashfilmMarch 24, 2011It received fiveAcademy Awardnominations at the84th Academy Awardsincluding:Academy Award for Best ActressBest Actressfor Rooney Mara,Academy Award for Best CinematographyBest Cinematography,Academy Award for Best Sound Editing,Best Sound Mixingand won one award forAcademy Award for Best Film EditingBest Film Editing.

Fincher is executive producer of theNetflixtelevision seriesHouse of Cards (U.S. TV series)House of Cards; he also directed the first two episodes.Cite newshttp://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/house-of-cards-premiere-date-netflix-kevin-spacey-david-fincher-376355The Hollywood ReporterNetflix Launching Entire Run of David Fincher's 'House of Cards' in One DayMichaelO'ConnellApril 10, 2012The series has received critical acclaim, receiving ninePrimetime Emmy AwardPrimetime Emmynominations, includingPrimetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Drama SeriesOutstanding Drama Seriesand Fincher forPrimetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Directing for a Drama SeriesOutstanding Directing for a Drama Seriesfor the first episode, which he won.House of Cards | Academy of Television Arts & Sciences. Emmys.com. Retrieved on 2014-02-01.

Fincher directedGone Girl (film)the adaptationofGillian Flynn's novelGone Girl (novel)Gone Girl,cite newshttp://variety.com/2013/film/news/david-fincher-may-have-found-next-girl-1118064952/David Fincher may have found next ‘Girl’January 22, 2013Varietycite webhttp://www.deadline.com/2013/07/ben-affleck-gone-girl-movie-david-fincher/Ben Affleck To Star In David Fincher’s ‘Gone Girl’ For Fox/New Regency Before Directing Warner Bros’ ‘Live By Night’July 11, 2013Production began in September 2013cite webhttp://thesouthern.com/news/gone-girl-filming-at-giant-city-state-park/article_a0982f54-1f53-11e3-be49-0019bb2963f4.html‘Gone Girl’ filming at Giant City State ParkSeptember 17, 2013and the film was released on October 3, 2014.cite newshttp://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/david-finchers-gone-girl-gets-648847'Gone Girl' Gets Fall 2014 Release; 'Frankenstein' Pushed to January 2015October 15, 2013The Hollywood ReporterPamelaMcClintockFincher signed a three-series deal withHBOforUtopia (UK TV series)Utopia,Shakedown, andLiving on Video. He was to handle the directing and writing duties for the first season of HBO's adaptation ofUtopia (UK TV series)Utopia, a British television series, but budget disputes between HBO and Fincher led to the project being cancelled in July 2015.cite webDavid Fincher HBO Pilot ‘Utopia’ In Jeopardy Over Budget Issueshttp://deadline.com/2015/07/david-fincher-pilot-utopia-jeopardy-hbo-1201488110/Deadline HollywoodNellieAndreeva30 July 201531 July 2015Shakedown, a noir-ish crime drama, set in LA in the 1950s, is about a tabloid world and the underbelly of Los Angeles in the 1950s and centers on a real-life private detective. It is inspired by the life of legendary 1950s Hollywood vice cop-turned-private eye Fred Otash.http://www.slashfilm.com/hbo-series-shakedown/Fincher will be producing the series while authorJames Ellroywill be developing the series. This will be Fincher's second TV project afterHouse of Cardson Netflix, which also attracted actor Kevin Spacey.http://www.empireonline.com/news/story.asp?NID=42322Living on Video, a comedy set in the 1980s, will follow Robby, a college drop out, pursuing his dream as a music video and film director in Hollywood.http://deadline.com/2014/12/david-fincher-1980s-comedy-music-video-hbo-1201329932/Red Band SocietyactorCharlie Rowewill play the lead role after Tyler Ross dropped out due to conflicts.http://deadline.com/2015/02/david-fincher-living-on-video-charlie-rowe-cast-hbo-1201378226/
article.heading: Personal life
article.paragraph: Fincher married model-photographer Donya Fiorentino in 1990 and divorced in 1995. They have a daughter. Fiorentino went on to marry actorGary Oldman.Fincher has since been in a long-term relationship with producerCen Chaffin, who has gone on to produce all of his films starting with 1997'sThe Game (1997 film)The Game.http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/david-fincher-complex-mind-social-95704?page=3

article.heading: Music videos
article.paragraph: As a music video director, Fincher has won twoGrammy Award for Best Music VideoGrammy Awards for Best Music Video, for his work in "Love Is Strong" byThe Rolling Stones(1995) and "Suit & Tie" byJustin TimberlakeandJay-Z(2013), and threeMTV Video Music Award for Best DirectionMTV Video Music Awards for Best Direction, being one of the most awarded directors in the category, alongsideSpike Jonze. He also earned back-to-back MTV Video Music Awards for Best Direction in 1989 for "Express Yourself" and in 1990 for "Vogue". In 1990, he earned three of the four available nominations in the Best Direction category.

template.arg: David Fincher Didn’t Want To Make ‘Another Serial-Killer Movie’ … Until ‘Zodiac’ Came Along - Part I
